verses.text: What shall we say then? Should we continue in sin so that grace may increase?
verses.comment: Paul raises a rhetorical question, challenging the idea that greater sin could bring about greater grace. The passage stresses that grace is not an excuse for ongoing sin.

verses.text: Absolutely not! How can we who died to sin still live in it?
verses.comment: Paul rejects any idea of continuing in sin once we are united to Christ. The spiritual reality is that Christians are fundamentally transformed.

verses.text: Or do you not know that all of us who have been baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?
verses.comment: Baptism is presented here as a real participation in the death of Christ, not merely symbolic. Early Christian tradition regarded baptism as the means of entering into Christ’s saving work.

verses.text: Therefore, we were buried with him by baptism into death, so that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, we also might walk in newness of life.
verses.comment: Baptism's burial and resurrection motif links believers intimately with Christ’s death and resurrection. The Christian is called to an actual transformation—a ‘new life’, not just a change of status.

verses.text: For if we have been united with him in a death like his, we will certainly also be united with him in a resurrection like his.
verses.comment: Paul grounds our hope for resurrection upon our union with Christ, begun in baptism. This implies both a present spiritual reality and a future bodily resurrection.

verses.text: We know that our old self was crucified with him so the body of sin might be destroyed, that we should no longer be slaves to sin.
verses.comment: Paul teaches a real interior change—our sinful self is put to death. This emphasizes the actual power of grace in sanctification.

verses.text: For one who has died has been freed from sin.
verses.comment: Death brings release from the power of sin, a truth experienced spiritually in Christian life. The commentary draws upon both legal and spiritual meanings.

verses.text: Now if we have died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him.
verses.comment: Paul connects our future hope of resurrection to participation in Christ’s death—a core theme uniting Old Testament anticipation with New Covenant fulfilment.

verses.text: We know that Christ, being raised from the dead, will never die again; death no longer has mastery over him.
verses.comment: Christ’s resurrection is final and eternal—foreshadowed in Isaiah 25:8 and realized fully in Christ. The passage upholds Christ’s victory over death for all believers.

verses.text: For the death he died, he died to sin once for all, but the life he lives, he lives to God.
verses.comment: Christ’s one sacrifice is sufficient, echoed in Hebrews. His new life is wholly directed to God, setting the pattern for believers.

verses.text: So consider yourselves dead to sin and alive to God in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: Paul exhorts Christians to critically embrace their new identity, actively living out the mystery of dying and rising with Christ.

verses.text: Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal bodies so that you obey its desires.
verses.comment: Paul insists that Christians are called to real purity and transformation, not just justification. This highlights both the moral and spiritual dimension of salvation.

verses.text: Do not offer your members to sin as instruments of unrighteousness, but offer yourselves to God as those alive from the dead, and your members as instruments of righteousness to God.
verses.comment: Paul’s language implies the profound dignity and responsibility of the Christian body, which is to be consecrated to God—a spiritual act echoing Old Testament sacrifices.

verses.text: For sin will not have mastery over you, since you are not under law but under grace.
verses.comment: Freedom from sin is a reality for those in Christ. The passage nuances the difference between law and grace, drawing out the interior power bestowed by divine grace.

verses.text: What then? Should we sin because we are not under law but under grace? Absolutely not!
verses.comment: Paul’s repetition underlines that grace obligates us to holiness, not license. Grace empowers true obedience.

verses.text: Do you not know that if you offer yourselves to someone as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one you obey—either of sin, leading to death, or of obedience, leading to righteousness?
verses.comment: Paul’s dichotomy frames our choices in terms of spiritual slavery, with the goal of true righteousness—reminiscent of Old Testament calls to covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: But thanks be to God! You who were slaves to sin have become obedient from the heart to the standard of teaching entrusted to you.
verses.comment: Paul highlights the importance of heartfelt obedience to apostolic teaching, as a transformative force in the believer.

verses.text: And having been freed from sin, you became slaves of righteousness.
verses.comment: True freedom, according to Paul, is found in wholehearted service to righteousness—a life conformed to Christ’s teachings.

verses.text: I am speaking in human terms because of your natural limitations. For just as you once offered your members as slaves to impurity and lawlessness leading to greater lawlessness, so now offer your members as slaves to righteousness leading to holiness.
verses.comment: Paul acknowledges human frailty but calls us to true sanctification—holiness through participation in righteousness.

verses.text: For when you were slaves to sin, you were free in relation to righteousness.
verses.comment: Sin enslaves by separating us from righteousness—a motif developed throughout Scripture about covenant faithfulness and holiness.

verses.text: But what benefit did you gain from those things you are now ashamed of? For the end of those things is death.
verses.comment: Paul notes the emptiness of sinful living—the only natural outcome is death and shame, as witnessed in both Old and New Testament.

verses.text: But now that you have been freed from sin and have become slaves to God, the benefit you receive is holiness, and the end is eternal life.
verses.comment: Paul shows that sanctification is a process leading to eternal life, not just a momentary event. This calls the believer to a lifelong journey of holiness.

verses.text: For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.comment: Paul contrasts the consequence of sin—death—with the free gift of God: eternal life through union with Christ. The language points toward the necessity of remaining in Christ, and the journey of sanctification. The gift is only found ‘in Christ’ as part of his mystical body, echoing both spiritual and physical realities of salvation.
